name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Natural History

transcript.content: Hello, I'm Ricky Gervais. The English biologist Thomas Huxley once wrote: "To a person uninstructed in Natural History, his country or seaside stroll is a walk through a gallery filled with wonderful works of art. Nine-tenth of which have their faces turned to the wall. Teach him something of natural history, and you place in his hands a catalog of those which are worth turning around. To some, the wonders and intricacies of the natural world are a miracle. Living proof of the existence of God. To others the natural world is a wondrous illustration of Darwinian evolution. To discuss the complexities of plant and animal life, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, graduate of the University of Warwick and award-winning writer.
Thank you so much for having me.
And Karl Pilkington. A man with no qualifications, very little education, but who is now known the world over as a man with a head like a fucking orange.
Alight?
Intro music

Natural history obviously takes in everything to do with animals, plants, bacteria, which are in neither group. I should start by just saying Karl, that the natural world is so diverse that we don't even know how many species there are.

Conservatively, there's two million species of animals. I mean, without even taking in plant life, there are at least 2 million species of animal. With plants and animals, there could be up to 10 million species. There are 37 thousand different species of spider alone. What do you think of that?
It's a lot.
It is, isn't it?
But if there's loads of stuff out there that we don't know about, and we don't know what it's doing, is it that important? Is it worth finding them now?
Well yeah.
Why?
Well it may give us the key to unlock other mysteries.
A spider won't.
Well it might do.
A spider won't be unlocking any mysteries.
Well, that's totally...
Plants are different. I reckon there's a natural cure for everything out there.
No. No, cause there's loads of animals that have toxins that are used in medicine.
Yeah, I know that we use dangerous spiders to get rid of headaches or whatever or they do in the tribes, right?
Yeah well
Do you want to just expand on that point?
It's just that, that's what they do in tribes.
Who's they?

All these tribes that-- they've got all natural remedies that you know, they go "What's up with you? You got a sore ankle? Chew on this twig!" And it works. I've seen it, they send women out there and like, they can't believe the stuff they can do with twigs and trees, and hedgehogs and stuff.
Mmm. It wasn't an in-depth analysis, was it?
No. Women. They just send some women out there, apparently.
I reckon the the stuff that's got venom in it, that's useful... They probably know all about them.
What do you mean? It doesn't make any sense "we probably know all about them"...
What I mean is, the police know about the gangsters.
Right

But they go "Right, we're aware of them, let them get on with it. We'll keep our eye on them." And it's the same in the jungle. These spiders-- The deadly ones, you're aware of. The ones that are just pottering about, you go "Don't even worry about them. Don't even give them a name!"
Ricky laughs
They're not doing anything.
But what if there's another poisonous spider, they have not identified yet there, lurking in the undergrowth?
I'd be very surprised.
So you'd be very surprised.
I'd be surprised if he was something
It sounds like laziness on your part.
But they're discovering new species all the time.
We know about all the dangerous stuff now because we have to. We live in a world now--
No we don't.
We do, we know about a lot of the dangerous stuff. Whenever they find something new now it's like a new butterfly or--
Well n- well no, look at AIDS.
What?
When I was a kid, I'd- no one'd ever heard of AIDS.
Yeah but that's not a natural thing, is it? That's not like a spider or a la-ladybird--
What do you mean it's not 'a natural thing'?

It's not a, it's not a natural thing. It's not something that's-- AIDS hasn't been like living under the soil for millions of years going "I'll wait till the 1980s and then come out and kill a load of people."
No, but it is a natural thing.
It's a new thing, it's new!
Yeah, yeah, but loads of animal are new, aren't they? Not in, not- I mean, in, uh, in evolutionary terms, there's new animal in evolution.

I'm sure, I'm sure there's new stuff, deep down that's just like, almost like bacteria. Sat under the soil, it'll never come to the top, right? It's like having, having an old woman who's a neighbour. She never goes out. She doesn't bother you. Let her be.
Ricky laughs
B-b-but what if that old neighbour could unlock the secrets to--
I don't think she can
-just even to us understanding th-the complexities of the universe, and the way things have developed and grown?
'Cause we'd know about it.

Well, why would we know about it? Because, I never understand, why is it you want to stop researching and studying now? Why is it that you're happy t-to to just draw a line under everything else? What if people had said this back in the 19th century?
We've done this! We've done this! I think that someone in the 1900s - we'd, uh - said everything that's going to be invented has been invented. A-and then look what happened in that century.
Yeah, and I've said to you, "Look at the stuff that is being invented now. The Frisbee and stuff like that."
Ricky and Steve laugh
It's not- right--
It's all- it's all - it's all stuff that you kind of go, "It's alright, it's a good idea but it- we don't need it."
Yeah but the Frisbee wasn't being worked on by the top brains of our generation, that was some novelty toy that some manufacturer made!

Yeah but it's like look at the fuss we made over that fella who came up with the Dyson vac'. Everyone was like "He's up there with Einstein!" Well, he's not. Now it's a good vac', it cleans up floors well and everything but--
Who said he's up there with Einstein?
His PR people?
In one of- in one of those programmes where they did like, 'Great Inventions of Our Time.' It was easy early on, you go: Einstein, y'know, Newton did this, Archimedes, Dyson.
Ricky laughs

And that's- they started to run out because it is harder to come up with something new now, because, everything that's needed-- Remember, the things we've invented are things that we sort of go, "We could do with that." Inventors don't sit there going, "What can I make? Uhh, I need a toaster." They've sat there, they've burnt the toast under the grill and they've gone "I need some sort of device here that I can put bread in..."
Well some do, yeah yeah yeah yeah yeah.
"-and what can I- ah, I'll shape it like that, yeah--"
Necessity is the mother of invention.
Yeah.
However, there are, uh, uh, people who sit around going, "W-where's a, you know, a loophole in the market where there's a little-- where's a niche?"
Well h-here's something: about a year ago, I came up with a see-through toaster so that you can see how much the toast is cooked.
Right...
Found it about two months after that, someone had done it.
Alright.
So I'd just been beaten to the post.
Yeah, but all you're really doing, Karl, is modifying an existing invention.
That's- [mumbles] what other examples of being pipped at the post are there?
Well I did--
It's got to be one that hasn't been done or it's not your theory.
But what--
But also something that unlocks
...or helps the world.
What's causing problems in the world? At the moment, that needs sorting?
Well, cures for things... Faster transport... Anything to do with secure, anything to do with well-being. You know.
I mean, obviously environmental concerns are a big issue. People trying to design automobiles that you know, run on different-
Fuels.
Different, alternative fuels.

I met a bloke on a conference once, who sent a drawing to Blue Peter, it was their design of a car of the future, and he sent them a drawing that was a car and the only Innovation was that you can have a shit while driving.
Steve laughs
And then he put he put "Shit goes down pipe, which becomes fuel." They must have looked at that and gone "What a maniac!"
I think that's a brilliant. I mean, I've driven a long way- I went to Cornwall recently and I would have loved-
But I think he did it when he was about 9, and he must have thought "Ah, I'm being driven to school. Ah, I need a toilet! Wouldn't it be good if--?
But why hasn't been that done?
What?!
Liked Steve's said, I've been in the same situation when you're driving and you go "Ah, when's the service station?" And then you see a sign saying '36 miles'... You're in agony!
So what? So you suggest- Pull your trousers down, and shit down on the seat that's a toilet?
Yeah, what's wrong with that?
Well, you got your nan in the back!
She's got one as well.
So you are going to Cornwall, all shitting.
Not all the time, but it's more useful to me than a lighter!
So also, at what point--
Where do you wash your hands?
...You wash your hands or wipe your arse? At what point does that occur?
At the end of the journey.
Ricky laughs
(laughs) Oh god! So you get in, you have a shit at Deptford and you wipe your arse at Polperro?

But like I've said to you, this isn't like just people going "Ahh, I think I'll have one!" "You need one?" "Not really, but it's something to do innit?" "I'm sick of playing 'I spy', I'm having a shit!" You have it when you really need one. When you have to pull off a Motorway, it's a lot of messing about. There's probably going to be a queue at the toilet. No more queues at toilets!
10 minutes, Rick, that takes, doesn't it? 10 minutes to walk in and have a quick shit.
I know, yeah.

10 minutes. Driving along, just-- It's just going on. It's just going on. Don't even know about it. Radio's on. Everyone's happy. Doesn't matter. I don't know-- I mean, we all do it as well, that's the thing.
Anything else? That you'd come up with? I mean so far you have come up with nothing! That was a nine-year-old boy's idea.
I mean, the Breville maker wasn't needed.
(laughs) That's true!
What's that? Breville maker?

Like toasted sandwhiches. I mean, so many things... Chocolate fountains... Anything like that, I just go: "What are these? Who's invented these? Who's okayed this idea?" And yet you can't have a shit on the motorway?!
Ricky laughs
Think of computers!
What about them?
Well, I mean... that's in the... in the last few years, you know. In a 100 years in our existence, okay? They've been dabbling with anything even close to a computer... Nothing before that.
Yeah. Computers are a good thing, and it baffles me
As to how they came about. When you think a computer chip is just made out of sand. Now for someone to come up with that, you go "There must have been some sort of alien involved here!"
What do you mean?! Why do you say that?
Steve laughs
So I love it! So the Frisbee: rubbish! Anything to clever: "Well, it wasn't an invention, it was an alien!" So there's nothing between Frisbee and computer chip.
What I'm saying is it's not even an idea, is it?
What do you mean?
A computer chip? Where's that come from?
Oh, it is amazing! It's astounding, yeah.
So you think it was an alien? What are you talking about?
(laughs) That's great!
Because I can't believe that someone would go "Right. I want to make something that will hold information, and be able to do... I know! Let's use some sand! We've got loads of that." You go "What--"
Well that's what genius is though, isn't it?
But Karl, there's no alien involved!
No, but when I say "alien", I don't mean an alien came down here and said, you know, "Oh, do you want to buy this?" There could have been-
Yeah
...a spaceship crash, right?
Right. Yeah.

And there's all them room isn't there, in that hangar? They've got the spaceship, they take it apart... They go "Yeah wheels, we've got them. Yeah, yeah, yeah, steering wheel..." And they go "Hang on! What's this here?" And they find the chips and they break it down and they find it's sand.

Karl! But that, as an explanation to human genius, is nearly as ridiculous as the Adam and Eve explaining life on Earth. How could you tell that to someone without going red? I mean, I always worry about that, where people-- Like people who believe in Adam and Eve. Don't they wish there was a slightly better explanation? With all the evidence we've got? Do you know what I mean? With all the evidence for evolution. That they think the Earth is 5,000 years old, and God made Adam out of some dust(!) and then he went "Oh, I need a bird! It's alright, I'll make it out of your rib!"
There's loads of things that you go "Ah this is a bit embarrassing" I bet Charles Darwin, when he said "We've all come from apes" I bet he sat "Oh, should have talked about the Frisbee first!"
But the fact that sand makes computer chips is not the interesting thing, the interesting thing is how the human being discovered--
What am I talking about? "Sand makes computer chips..."
Steve giggles
That silicon can have information put on it. But we are made out of Oxygen, Nitrogen, Carbon, do you know what I mean? And hydrogen. And-
Yeah, but that's nature! You see a nature is amazing, you can't beat nature. Right?
No.
He comes up with some amazing things.

Yeah, but man is nature! Don't forget that we are-- We are an animal, we're a brilliant ape. Now it's clear to any sensible, reasonable, educated person that we did evolve from apes, or rather we had a common ancestry. And that we're closest to the chimpanzee. We're actually 98.6% genetically identical to a chimpanzee, Karl. We're closer to a chimp, than the chimp is to a gorilla. Genetically speaking.
But I just find that hard to believe-
Well I'm telling you, it's true, so what- what- What are you finding our to believe?
Well, your eyes... your own eyes are, what sort of comes up... with a lot of thoughts.
Yeah yeah, no. No. One is: Eyes don't come up with thoughts. Two: What you mean is, you look at things--
No, what I'm saying is, through your own eyes
You look at things and you make up your own decisions.
So if there's no Darwin or anything
Yeah.
And I was sat somewhere and some said "Right, we're going to bring a few animals in. One of them is related."
Right?
They're all related.
All right, but they're all related to you, but one's not so long ago, alright? And they brought 'em in and lined 'em up, and there was a chimp stood there and a gorilla.
And there's another one...
Orangutang?
Orangutang, so yeah, right. I'll go, "So the orangutan, send that out. That'll be first to go, so he's definitely not linked to me. Uh...
See, I'd disagree, but there we go, that's just looking at you.
Sort of the hair coloring. There's none of that in our family.
Well, there's no hair.
[Laughs] I like that fact that it looses out because it's ginger.
So that's gone, right? So I'm left with a gorilla and a chimp, I would go for the gorilla.
Well it was a good guess but you'd be wrong. We are much closer to the chimpanzee, okay? 98.6% genetically identical, think of that. We only differ on 1.4 percent of our genetic makeup.
Well, that-that-that must be the arse. Because that's a lot different.
Animal Rights is a hot topic.
It's a big issue.

What rights should they have? How do they compare to humans? You know, it's a well-known fact that we test on animals with the assumption that humans are more important. We test drugs on animals and we're basically saying, "If they die, they die. We'll learn something from them."
People do make distinctions between animals, right? They know that it's probably more acceptable to kill an ant than uh...
Punch a cow.
Yeah, exactly. You know it, I think that comes again from "How close are they to humans? Have they got a face? Are they furry."
Well that's the - I told, you know, about me, me Dad's mate, who had a monkey and he had to thump it.
What? One, well there's two things there, one, why did he have a monkey? Two, what sort of discipline is thumping monkey? What was the monkey doing?
It kept, it was annoying his wife a lot, and sort of, you know, pinching her ass and stuff like that.
That's not true.
Right, right, wait a minute, we've never heard this before. How have we had all these years of Monkey News and we've never heard this before?
No, Im sure I've told you about it ages ago.
Your dad had a mate that had a monkey?
Yeah, I'm sure told you.
That - why did he have a monkey? Just for a laugh?
Well, it was back in the day when people did - they all had like odd - sort of pets, didn't they?
When?
In like 'bout '68.
Oh, in 1968. Oh, when everyone had a monkey.
But he had to thump it. Now, the weird thing is though-
No, that's weird enough.
Is this the, this is all the story? This is the entire story you've got?
No-
All the information you've got is, "he had a monkey, and he had to thump it?
Yeah. My dad told me about it. When he found out that I was into monkeys he said, "Oh, Benny thumped one." and uh...

[Laughs] "Benny thumped one". "Oh, my son's into Natural History, particularly of the simian variety, I've got an interesting fact for you Karl, sit down.";"What is it Pater?"; "Um, Benny thumped one." Brilliant.
But what was interesting is, the way that, people are thumping other people all the time, no one bats an eyelid. Thump a monkey, people go, "You thumped a monkey."
Thumped a monkey.
Ricky laughs
Yes! Yes they do! They do go "You thumped a monkey!"
So that's what's weird innit?
Well this chimp doesn't want to be caged and kept in a fucking council house in Manchester!
No, it was- It was quite happy.
It wasn't happy!
And it was treated like a human. I mean in the 70s, you know, they were all the teabag adverts and all that, they were loving that.
No, they weren't loving it.
Now people interfere. People go "That's unfair!" Now they're in like a cage in the zoo. They go "It was better when I was pushing a piano up the stairs!"
They weren't really- They weren't really-
They weren't actual delivery men!
They weren't really sitting down and having a cup of tea!
It wasn't a documentary! A 'Week in the Life of Monkey Deliverymen'
I love that! Chimps in a zoo now go "Fuckin' hell, at least we were free."
"Do you remember, we used to drive a van?"
"And we were on 58 quid a week."
Yeah.
They're not meant to be kept in a house in Manchester. It's cold to keep a person in a house in Manchester, so it's fucking cold to keep a monkey... (laughs)
Are you aware, Karl, that 99% of all forms of life that have existed on Earth are now extinct?
So there's only one percent of everything, that's ever been, still alive.
Yeah.
But that's just as well, innit?
Why?

Well I think it's pretty crowded now. So it's just as well. You see, this is this is what I'm saying now, years ago they accepted that. Cavemen won't have been going "Well we're losing stuff. Stuff's dying." Whereas now everyone's: "Oh the panda! The polar bears! They've not got any ice!" And all that. At the end of the day the world's only so big. We know it's not getting any bigger. Right? Stuff's got to die, innit? You can't keep everything.

Just think of that though! Ss a tool of natural selection, that the species that are surviving today, all 1%. Just how amazing that is to survive and evolve. How perfect everything is on Earth? It's amazing.

No, but it will drop off again, won't it? As we're finding new stuff other stuff will be dying. In that 1%- When that was written, when that statement was made, was the Dodo gone or was it still here?
It was gone.
Pretty certain it was gone.
It was gone already?
It doesn't matter, does it? A percentage is a percentage.
Yeah. The Dodo went. The last Dodo died. They said that was the last Dodo. No more Dodos. But we found this-
Dido! Still making great tunes.
Great albums. Great albums.
Yeah we lost the Dodo, but we've got Dido!
Her recent albums not sold very well actually.
Dying out. Dying out. Everything has a lifespan.
Dido is dying out?
But- And I think that's that's life. So it's not amazing, really.
That's not alive then anymore.
No, that's- That's life's gone. That was good.
... forced to just hang around in the jungle. It's a shame.
When I went to Natural History Museum, there was a thing called "Siber ear" or something right? Died out ages ago. No one knows about it. Which is weird, because everyone knows about the Dodo.
Well, that's because it died out in- I think... that I was in the 18th century or something, it wasn't it?
Well... you know- Within...what we might know as some recent history.
Yeah
Well this this thing's sort of-- I don't think it was far behind it. It's just timing, innit? Got more press, the Dodo.
Now the "Siderear" -or whatever it's called- it was a big thing. It was a cross-
Well, you've seen it and you still don't know what it's called.
Well, it's a spelled awkwardly.
Steve laughs
But it's- They said it was a cross between a moose and a giraffe.
Ricky laughs
Now we don't need that, do we? At no point of have we said "You know, what we need here? To get us through this?"
Well that's funny because when they first named the giraffe they called it, 'Camelopard', because they thought was a cross between a camel and a leopard.
Really?
Yeah.

Well I can tell you that when zoologists examined a platypus for the first time, some of them thought it might have been a hoax. Because they thought it could have been different parts of different animals sewn together. Because the Platypus has the fur of an otter, the tale of a beaver, the bill and feet of a duck and the venomous spurs of a fighting game cock. So, they assumed that...
It's like a Scrapheap Challenge of animals?
Ricky laughs
Yeah! I remember, right-
Well actually-
Sorry, no, go on!
Just to clarify that: they actually descended from a link between reptiles and mammals. Almost 150 million years ago,  sort of a living fossil.
When I was about 13-14, I once tried to improve the Animal Kingdom, by making the hardest animal ever. The most perfect animal.
Now, just to clarify, you didn't in sort of Frankenstein's style try and bolt various bits of animals together?
No. It was a drawing that I sent in to Blue Peter. There was no competition going on!
You just thought they would be appreciative of it.
I thought they'd look at that, and they'd go "Well, this is- these are genius! This is like DaVinci!"
Sure.

And this is the animal-- this is what I thought the perfect animal-- I mean, when I say perfect, I meant the hardest animal. This animal, it could take anything. It was just the strongest, hardest, fastest, right?
Yeah.
So I started with the head of a lion.
'Course! That makes sense.
Do you know what I mean? "Arghh!" It looks good. Bite you, right? Okay. I popped that on the body of a rhinoceros.
Okay, so it's got the toughness, the armor if you will.

Oh! Full strength... Head of a lion, think of that- So you've got this picture: head of a lion, body of a rhino. Okay? Hold on though! Pop some arms on it! The front arms of it, were the arms of a gorilla.
The arms of a gorilla! Okay.
So punch, grip, it could make stuff-- The lion, that's where the lion falls down, because it can't make stuff.
Sure.
It can't climb... You know. So. Okay then. Wait a minute! You think that's got enough weaponry?
Sounds like it.
No! Pop on the tail of a giant scorpion.
A giant scorpion?
Yeah. Yeah.
So it's a scorpion that's the size of a rhinoceros?
Exactly! So the tail was as long as that, right? So now this is a scary animal! And this where the animal fell down. I thought, "Right, legs! Well, the fastest animal is the cheetah"
The cheetah.
Popped on four cheetah legs.
Four cheetah legs.
It would have collapsed.
Crushed under the weight of the rhinoceros.
It would have collapsed immediately. So...
You drew this, did you?
Yeah.
Did you show it to anyone else?
Yeah, my mates went "That's brilliant!"
Right.
They said that's brilliant.
And then just sent straight to Blue Peter...
Yeah.
Any reply?
No reply at all! No reply at all
Really? That's a surprise
What do you think of that, Karl?
What would you? How would you though? What would, if you wanted to make the ultimate fighting animal, what would you come up with?
If you have the power like that fella in Arabian Nights 'size of a chimpanzee', you could change into anything, but you could change into, you know, like that.
I don't think I'd go for strength and that. I'd go for survival.
What would you do, cockroach?
No, I'd have uhh. I'd have like uhhh, An armadillos body
Right, okay? So that's that, that's as big as you can be now then. So you can't really pop on a lion's head 'cause it'd just lay there going "I can't fucking move".
Alright
I'd have uh, head of an owl
Right?
Head of an owl?
Yeah. Why what come on? Why what does that bring to the table?
The heads there to sort of make it look friendly to the human race. So because if you look half decent to the human race, they'll look after you.
Right
That's the way it works, right
Okay?
Like a cat and a dog an' all that. Mmm. So the Owl makes it look nice.
Right.
I'd have uhhh, I wouldn't have legs, I'd go for like the slug juice.
Laughs. What do you mean? So now, you're a really slow moving, legless armadillo, with the head of an owl?
Slithering along. How is that gonna be friendly? They'll see the beautiful face. But then they'll be terrified by the sludge.
No, because the heads that nice, they'll, they'll forego the uh, sludge.

But hold on though. But wait a minute. So, there's got this thing that's stuck, right? Going at nought point one miles an hour. With it going "hoooo", right? You come over, you kick the head off. How is this?
No, Because the head can go into the thing like a tortoise
Can it?
Yeah. Course it can, into the armadillo body.
Well no, an armadillo doesn't do that. It just curls up into a ball.
But this isn't an armadillo, is it?
So it's...ohh.
Why has it got the slug. Why is that so attractive?
Cause I'm thinking, what I'm thinking is, an armadillo, they're good when they're on their feet. Flip 'em. They get stuck, like a tortoise
Right
Slug stuff, keeps it down. So if anything attacks it, it's like a limpet or one of them things that can go.
Well have a limpet then
But but but it can't get anywhere, how- it can barely move it
Just go, just go and kick it, just.
What do you mean it can't get anywhere?
But how can it escape from danger, it's gonna move very slowly
Rubbish, what that's the worst animal
It can lock itself in. It'll lock itself in
Yeah, and then I just scoop it up on the sou-
You can't scoop it up. It locks itself in, if it's in danger, I'd give it peacock feathers.
Laughs. This is the worst animal I've ever heard
Why has it got peacock feathers?
Again it's just, it's just uh
This is the worst animal you- I've ever heard
Why has it got peacock feathers?
Threatening. It looks more threatening.
It does- right, that's the least threatening thing, peacock feathers. Like Danny La Rue coming at ya. There's nothing remotely scary about peacock feathers.
Yeah, to humans
Yeah?
But the humans won't be harming it because they like the owl head, people will like to have these things in the garden.
Hmm
Uhh, they eat lettuce

Laughs, They eat lettuce, they eat let- why has it got a beak? They eat lettuce, he's telling me what it's gonna eat now? The owls going "fuck that. I want a mouse". I love the fact that he's based what it eats on the fact that how it moves, a bit like a slug.
Yeah
That eat lettuce, it moves that and then it eat lettuce.
Like I said, it's not that weird. If that if that existed, if that was normal, like when you went out to empty your bin, there's one of them sliding up the wall.
Laughs
You wouldn't, you wouldn't even double take, you'd just be like "oh there's the uh, owl-head peacock feathered thing".
I don't know why it's climbing walls in an effort to find lettuce?
Yeah. Why is it climbing up that wall?
Because that's the only way it can see properly. Because his head's coming out like that.
Ricky laughs silently
So even though you've designed this animal, now it's-- Your even expanding its limitations.
Now its got problems!
Well, it is mainly made to be on walls
Ricky laughs
Because what else is living on walls?
(laughs) Oh god! Oh, fuckin' hell! What a useless animal that is. Karl, I mean!
But nature chucks up odd things, don't it?
Don't! Why are we starting on this again?
No! I'm just-- I'm just saying that is nature. Now and again you'll get- you'll get stuff that...
Oh, was he looking at you?
Yeah.
Was he really? (laughs)
Look at his fucking head! Look at your stupid round, fucking orangey head, ah...
Why aren't you a freak? You've got a little bald head. We're not meant to be bald.

Well, I was I think. That's the thing. That's what nature's done. You see I didn't do anything with my hair, when I had hair. I didn't style it, I didn't do anything with it and he probably thought "What I'm doing here?"
Steve & Ricky laughs
Whereas people who love their hair, and they comb it and have different styles and look after it, they have hair for ages.
Nonsense.
No! Nonsense. Absolute nonsense.
Well, you say that.
Absolute nonsense.

That's a little bit weird then, innit? 'Cause that's what happens with old people, once they lose their, you know, will to live. Once they lose the job, they get old. What's my purpose? What am I doing here? And it's like nature goes "You're not needed!" And they die. Maybe that's what happened with the dodo. What's it doing? Can't fly. Its wings are useless. Eat it, tastes horrible. Kill it.
Steve laughs
Now, they did eat it. I think they did eat it.
Yeah. But he wasn't very nice, was it?
I think-- I think they over-farmed it, I think that's why it was extinct. Because they did eat it.
No but they did eat it, but they didn't like it. Everybody-- You never- you never saw like a fully and carcass of a Dodo.
You're making this up again! All conjecture.
No, but they didn't eat it all. Everybody would probably try it and go "It's not for me, that."
But you don't know this!
No idea! You're just making this up.
What's this based? That people-- And also, why would that kill it out?
Because I'll tell you why!
Why?

Because if it's not nice, people go "Don't get another one in!" And they die out. The reason we've got loads of chickens and loads of 'cowses', is because we eat them. If we ate polar bears, we won't be short of them. Because you'd farm it! You'd take more care. But what's a polar bear doing? Sat on a block of ice, floating about.
Ricky & Steve laugh
It's no use to us! It sounds harsh-
Once again, he got his information from Glacier Mint advert.
No. It's no use to us. We know they're there, and it's all very sad when you see one on the news sort of struggling and all that.
Yeah
But it's going to make them stronger.
If scientists could bring back to life, the creatures that have existed in the past... You think that's a good idea or a bad idea?
Bad idea.
Bad idea? Now, leaving aside the horrors of Jurassic Park, do you think for research purposes it might be a useful idea?
I don't think it is. For me, it's like a Friends Reunited.
Steve laughs

It's like- It's like people who you knew ages ago, getting back in touch and you go "I don't want to get in touch with you." That was then! And it's the same with a mammoth. That was then. You had your day, it didn't work out. Now to bring it back, it's unfair. You're messing with nature anyway- I think I've said to you before about, I don't know what they'd do with them? They're massive things! I think-- It's like they're just not thinking about-- It's like rushing into buying furniture that's my
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Pleasurable.
So
But...
My pleasure, er, pleasure nerve
(Laughs)
That you talking about in my head. It lights up when I have a Twix.
I don't think it ever lights up, right? I don't think you've got a pleasure nerve
But it lights up when I have a Twix.
Right
It lights up, err... If there's something, if there's some chicken, right? It lights up if there's a...
Fuck me, what a miserable cunt he is.
You know, all all loads of things...
Chicken and Twix
That's it, that's all he lives for, hang yourself mate.
So what you're saying is; if I had that device that the rat's got, I'd just sit there wouldn't I? Hitting it, thinking "I cant be bothered going to the shop for a Twix. I'll just hit this button".

Yeah... think of this. So, aggressive is the horned frog of Argentina, that people believe that, if the Frog bites the lip of a horse, the horse will die. Actually, the Frog's mouth contains no poison. It earned its fearsome reputation because it attacks animals many times its size. What do you think of a frog attacking a horse?
It's ridiculous, I don't know what's going on.
I don't know why that would happen. Why is it getting upset with a horse? Of all the things for a frog to be like, getting cocky with, them two should never even meet!
(Laughing) Why? Why? Why?
Because it's not, I mean fights, are normally 'over' something, aren't they?
Yeah.
If you have a fight with someone, "you're in my yard" or....
Yeah.
You know, It's, it's, your fighting over something.
I love the fact that he immediately goes back to the 1930s.
Yeah.
You're in my yard!
But, a horse and a Frog. How did that disagree ...
What are they squabbling over?
I don't, I don't understand what they've got in common. I don't, I don't understand it. I bet that's only happened once, it's a rare incident, someone said "put that in a book".
(Laughs)
I can't imagine it. That that's happening a lot, that horses are being bit by frogs all over the shop.
(Laughs)

I saw this trailer... for this documentary that said er, "The man who's having a baby", and I turned on, and it's a woman... going through a sex change and she's pregnant. That's not a man having a baby. That's a woman having a beard.
Having a breakdown.

What, why is that? What? That's a con, that is pure sense.... "There's as a man, having a baby, look; world's first..." no its a woman, it's a woman, What do you think of that? What would you do? If you were a doctor and I came to you and went, "Karl, listen, I'm having a bit of a rethink of these. Er, I don't...the penis, I hate it. I hate this cock.
But what do you mean you hate it?
I hate. I don't want it there, it doesn't look right? Doesn't look right. It just sits there resting on these fucking awful testicles, that I'm going to get rid of. I want, I want this thrown away.
Yeah. Well it's you know, they're not a great look. I know that, everyone knows that, it's just the way they are.
And if we're all being honest, they're an odd design. I don't think anyone likes their own, do they?
Ricky laughs
That's why we cover 'em. They're not a great thing, are they?
Wha- that's not why we cover 'em though, is it?
It's part of it, I think. I think deep down, I mean, even if like, I know you hate the Adam and Eve thing, but even if back then he was like, "Good God, cover 'em up!"
Ricky laughs
Even he had a leaf on.
[Laughing] No, but it's... So are you thinking fundamentally then, that aesthetically, the testicles and the penis isn't as good as it could be? What would you have there instead? [Sniffs]
Well, it-it's designed that way 'cause that's the way it's got to be designed. It's more about function than, uh-
Yeah.
An-and that's, that's the thing innit - with, with modern technology--
[Mumbling] The thing is, the testicles have to be outside because they have to be a few degrees below body temperature.
Yeah.

Otherwise the sertoli cells die, which sort of feed the semen and all that. So, th-that you know, t-to be functioning and sort of like fertile, they have to be outside, which is annoying because I'd put a little ribcage round 'em like that [Ricky clicks his fingers]. I-I'd pop a ribcage round those, protect 'em. Wear a cricket box, have that built-in so you cannot get a kick in, a swift kick in the bollocks, that makes you feel sick.
No but it'd-- but it'd be better if they could sort of reverse up--
Steve laughs
In a way that they w- they w- they were hidden away, so that they were just-- then you dropped 'em. It's like, "Right, we need to cool 'em down. Be at it in about half an hour."
Yeah.
[Whooshes] Drop 'em down.

Yeah, like the gear on a, on an aeroplane. Landing gear, yeah. [Imitating a pilot] "And, uh, landing gear down and the bollocks and the cooling down." Or you can just like, just pop 'em in the fridge for 10 minutes.
It's like--
What, they could detach and you can pop them in the fridge to cool them down?
Yeah. Can you make me some breasts?
Easy.
Okay. Go on - you say 'easy,' what're you gonna do? What's your plan?
Just, uh... How do you do that? It's tablets innit?
[Laughing] No, but...
'Testerone' innit?
Ricky laughs
'Testerone'?
Toblerone. I want, yeah, I want some Toblerone.
Well, sort of pointy, pointy tits like Madonna.
Ricky laughs

Where do you stop though? Supposing I came to you and I said, uh... "Doctor, listen. Um, I like the bollocks, I like the penis, but I don't like 'em where they are. I'd... I want them, I want them in the middle of me chest. I want breasticles. Yeah? The arse? I don't like it round the back, I can't see what's going on. Pop that on the front where the bollocks were. I want my arse where I can look down and see what's going on. Can you do it?"
I think it's just easier to move the head.
Steve chuckles and Ricky explodes with laughter

Rick, I know you're a big fan of Professor Richard Dawkins, the evolutionary biologist. He wrote a book, uh, 'The Ancestor's Tale' in which he predicted a post-human world. Uh, this was his, you know, his kind of hypothesis if we were t-t-to uh... well, let me read what he's written. [Quoting] "If nuclear war destroys humanity and most of the rest of life, a good bet for survival in the short-term and for evolutionary ancestry in the long-term is rats."

I have a post Armageddon Vision. We and all the other large animals are gone. Rodents emerge as the ultimate posthuman scavengers. They gnaw their way through New York, London and Tokyo, digesting spilled larders, ghost supermarkets and human corpses, and turning them into new generations, of rats and mice. Whose racing populations explode out of the cities and into the countryside. When all the relics of human profligacy are eaten, populations crash again and the rodents turn on each other and on the cockroaches, scavenging with them. In a period of intense competition, short generations, perhaps with radioactivity enhanced mutation rates, boost rapid evolution. With human ships and planes gone, islands become islands again, with local populations, isolated, save for occasional lucky raftings. Ideal conditions for evolutionary divergence. Within five million years, a whole range of new species replace the ones we know. Herds of giant grazing rats are stalked by saber-toothed, predatory rats. Given enough time, will a species of intelligent cultivated rats emerge? Will rodent historians and scientists eventually organize careful archaeological digs? And through the struts of our long compacted cities reconstruct the peculiar and temporary tragic circumstances that gave ratkind, it's big break?
Karl. Thoughts?
7 seconds of dead air
I mean who knows what's going to happen?
Ricky laughs
Well, that's about it for the second, in the series of the Ricky Gervais Guide To. That was Natural History.
I think we've left no stone unturned there, Rick.

I think that is a definitive work. If you've enjoyed the Ricky Gervais Guide To Natural History, why not go back and listen to the Ricky Gervais Guide To Medicine, if you haven't already? Or even if you have! Because it would be like a revision.
Exactly.
Do you do know what I mean?
There will be a test!
There will be-- There won't be a test.
There won't be a test.
We can't be bothered... And next in the series is the Ricky Gervais Guide To The Arts. So look forward to that.
Sorry! Just to clarify: That's the ARTS.
Yeah
Right.
Not the arse! The Arts.
Sorry, just the way you speak...
Well yeah, right, I mean... Shouldn't have a go the ways people speak, you Wurzel...
Well yeah, just be clear, be clear...
Yeah yeah... (mumbles) ... You bumbling fool!
And we won't even get onto Karl Pilkington. Dopey... Cock. Anyway! Thank you very much from me, Ricky Gervais. With me, Stephen Merchant.
Goodbye.
And Karl Pilkington.
Alright?
Outro music
Audible hopes you have enjoyed this program.

trivia.description: Breville maker: A brand of sandwich, toaster maker.

Karl is presumably talking about Sivatherium, an extinct genus of giraffids that ranged throughout Africa to the Indian subcontinent. The species Sivatherium giganteum is, by weight, one of the largest giraffids known, and also one of the largest ruminants of all time. Presumed to have died out around 8000 years ago.
Scrapheap Challenge is a British television show where teams of contestants build a working machine that can perform a specific task, using materials available in a scrapyard.
Friends Reunited was a portfolio of social networking websites based upon the themes of reunion with research, dating and job-hunting.
